Introduction

Carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning is a potentially lethal condition caused by inhaling CO gas.  CO binds to hemoglobin with great affinity, displacing oxygen to create carboxyhemoglobin.  This limits the oxygen-carrying capacity of blood and decreases the release of oxygen into the tissues.  CO also directly impairs oxygen utilization by the mitochondria.  Manifestations of mild to moderate CO toxicity include headache, nausea, dyspnea, and malaise.  Severe poisoning can cause syncope, seizure, coma, arrhythmia, and death.  Diagnosis is confirmed by an elevated serum carboxyhemoglobin level, and treatment is immediate administration of 100% oxygen via a nonrebreather mask or within a hyperbaric chamber.

Risk factors



CO is a colorless, odorless, and tasteless gas produced by incomplete hydrocarbon combustion.  Potential sources of CO exposure include:



  • Smoke inhalation from a fire
  • Malfunctioning or improperly installed heating appliances (eg, furnace)
  • Poorly vented fuel-burning devices (eg, charcoal grills, kerosene heaters)
  • Motor vehicle exhaust in enclosed spaces (eg, garage)


Unintentional CO poisoning occurs most commonly during the winter in cold climates and after natural disasters that result in increased use of gasoline-powered generators.

Pathophysiology



CO causes toxicity by reducing systemic oxygen delivery and impairing cellular oxygen utilization.

Impaired oxygen delivery



  • CO binds to hemoglobin with an affinity approximately 250 times that of oxygen, thereby reducing the number of heme binding sites available to oxygen (normally 4) and causing a large reduction in the oxygen-carrying capacity of hemoglobin (
    figure 1
    ).
  • The formation of carboxyhemoglobin (even if only 1 of 4 sites is affected) triggers an allosteric change in the remaining oxygen binding sites, which increases their affinity for oxygen and impedes the unloading of oxygen in the tissues.  This is reflected by a leftward shift in the hemoglobin dissociation curve (
    figure 2
    ).

Impaired oxygen utilization



  • CO disrupts oxidative phosphorylation in the mitochondria, inhibiting aerobic metabolism and exacerbating cellular hypoxia.
  • CO is also capable of binding cardiac myoglobin with high affinity, disrupting the heart's ability to use oxygen and decreasing cardiac output.

Clinical presentation



The signs and symptoms of CO poisoning are variable, relatively nonspecific, and may overlap with other, more common, conditions (eg, viral syndrome).  In addition, the severity of illness from CO exposure can vary greatly from person to person.



Symptoms of mild to moderate CO poisoning include (

figure 3
):



  • Headache (most common)
  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Dizziness
  • Drowsiness/fatigue (in young children, this can present as irritability or difficulty feeding)
  • Shortness of breath
  • Chest pain
  • Vision changes


Severe CO poisoning is characterized by the following:



  • Cerebral hypoxia:  altered mental status, seizures, syncope, hypoxic brain injury, coma
  • Myocardial injury:  ventricular arrhythmias, myocardial ischemia and infarction (ECG changes, elevated cardiac enzymes), pulmonary edema (due cardiac dysfunction or CO-induced alveolar damage), hypotension
  • Anion gap metabolic acidosis:  elevated lactic acid level caused by anaerobic metabolism, which occurs due to impaired oxygen utilization

Physical examination



  • Vital signs may reveal tachycardia and tachypnea but can be unremarkable.
  • Pulse oximetry remains normal despite cellular hypoxia.  Pulse oximetry is used to measure the ratio of oxyhemoglobin (hemoglobin carrying oxygen) to the total amount of available hemoglobin.  It cannot differentiate oxyhemoglobin from carboxyhemoglobin (hemoglobin bound by CO).  Both are detected as "oxygenated" hemoglobin, creating a falsely elevated hemoglobin oxygen saturation (SpO2).
  • The appearance of cherry-red skin and mucous membranes is a rare and unreliable diagnostic sign.

Diagnosis



Recognition of CO poisoning can be difficult due to variable, nonspecific symptoms.  The condition should be considered when several people in a shared environment develop symptoms or when history suggests a potential exposure (eg, fire).  The diagnosis is best confirmed via arterial blood gas analysis revealing elevated carboxyhemoglobin levels in symptomatic patients.

Laboratory evaluation



When CO poisoning is suspected, evaluation must include measuring the patient's carboxyhemoglobin level.  Normal levels are <3% in patients who do not smoke and <10% in patients who smoke.  Levels >20% indicate significant CO exposure.  Carboxyhemoglobin levels are not always correlated with severity of illness or mortality risk; therefore treatment should be based on the patient's clinical appearance (not just the level).



Additional laboratory tests to consider when CO poisoning is suspected or confirmed:



  • Lactic acid:  Peripheral tissue hypoxia causes increased lactate production.
  • Arterial blood gas:  Anion gap metabolic acidosis is expected (lactic acidosis).
  • Cardiac enzymes:  These may be elevated due to myocardial ischemia and injury.
  • Complete metabolic panel:  This should be performed to evaluate for ischemic injury to the kidneys or liver.


An ECG should also be obtained during the evaluation.  Ischemic changes on ECG suggest severe CO toxicity with myocardial injury.

Imaging



  • X-ray of the chest:  Pulmonary edema, resulting from the toxic effects of CO on alveolar membranes and cardiac myocytes, is a sign of significant CO poisoning.
  • CT or MRI of the brain:  These may be useful in cases of severe poisoning to assess for hypoxic brain injury or hemorrhage.  MRI is more sensitive, particularly for detecting abnormalities in the globus pallidus and other basal ganglia structures (areas highly sensitive to hypoxic conditions).

Differential diagnosis



Due to the variability of symptoms observed in CO poisoning, several conditions may present similarly:



  • Influenza:  can present with symptoms that may include fatigue and headache, but patients typically have associated fever, cough, rhinorrhea, sore throat, and myalgias.
  • Migraine:  can present with headache, nausea, and vomiting, but there is usually a previous history of similar headaches, and patients often have sensitivity to light and sound.
  • Meningitis:  can cause headaches, fatigue, and nausea, but most patients also have fever and/or nuchal rigidity.
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA):  may cause altered mental status and metabolic acidosis, but hyperglycemia and ketonuria is also expected.

Management



The treatment of acute CO poisoning is removing the CO source and providing oxygen therapy:



  • Immediate administration of 100% oxygen via a nonrebreather mask.  The oxygen is able to compete with CO binding to hemoglobin and decreases the half-life of CO.

    • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy is indicated in severe cases, such as those associated with loss of consciousness, severe metabolic acidosis (pH <7.25), cardiac injury, hypotension, or neurological impairment.  Hyperbaric therapy provides 100% oxygen at a higher-than-normal air pressure, greatly increasing oxygen levels in the blood.  The best results are achieved if therapy is started within 6 hours of CO exposure.
  • Supportive care includes managing associated arrhythmias, seizures, acidosis, and hypotension.
  • Patients with an intentional CO exposure (eg, suicide attempt) should be referred to a psychiatrist for further assessment and treatment once stabilized.


Patients with mild symptoms that improve with high-flow oxygen can often be discharged, whereas those with severe findings or lack of improvement should be hospitalized.

Prognosis



The prognosis of CO poisoning often depends on the severity of presenting symptoms and the promptness of intervention.  Patients with mild to moderate symptoms generally recover completely if treated promptly.  In contrast, patients who present with severe symptoms of cerebral or myocardial ischemia have a worse prognosis.  Severe cases can result in permanent cardiac dysfunction, neurologic and cognitive deficits, and, in some cases, death.



A potential sequelae of CO toxicity is delayed neuropsychiatric syndrome, which occurs in up to 40% of cases.  It is characterized by cognitive deficits, behavioral/personality changes, memory loss, and motor dysfunction that can develop days to weeks after significant CO exposure.

Summary



Carbon monoxide poisoning (
